fields.label_text: Silver Galleries Discovery Area Display (Room 66, Case 5) from 14 June 2013 Shown alongside the Cowper Seal Cups (M.10-M.11-2013) Introductory Panel: PERKS OF OFFICE: SEAL CUPS These large cups commemorate the careers of two high-ranking government officials of the early 18th century. Both Sir Nathan Wright and William Cowper, 1st Earl Cowper served as Lord Keeper of the Great Seal, a responsibility held today by the Lord Chancellor. The Great Seal is a silver die, in two parts, from which a wax impression is made and attached to documents of state drawn up by the government. The wax impression marks the monarch's official approval. The law requires that when there is a change of monarch, or of national jurisdiction, the Great Seal must be replaced. Wright and Cowper held the Great Seal during a time of royal and political transformation. In 1702, Queen Anne succeeded William III, and, in 1707, The Act of Union joined England and Scotland under a single government, creating the state of Great Britain. Each momentous national change demanded a new Great Seal. For Wright and Cowper, a centuries-old tradition enabled them to keep the redundant seals and have them melted down and turned into display cups to mark their time in office. This tradition was referred to as a perquisite, from which evolved our modern word 'perk'. Object Label: THE WRIGHT SEAL CUP Silver-gilt London, around 1705 Maker's mark for Phillip Rollos I or II Engraved with the arms of Sir Nathan Wright (1654-1721) This cup marks Sir Nathan Wright's time as Lord Keeper of the Great Seal from 1700-1705. Queen Anne presented William III's Great Seal to Wright on her accession in 1702. William's portrait, on the front of this cup, is made from the metal of the seal. Anne's portrait is on the other side. Wright was an unwilling Lord Keeper. Anne was equally reluctant about his appointment, wishing "there had been a worthier man in the kingdom to whom she could have delivered it". The Rosalinde and Arthur Gilbert Collection on loan to the Victoria and Albert Museum LOAN:GILBERT.587-2008

fields.descriptive_line: The Wright Seal cup and cover. Silver-gilt. Probably Phillip Rollos I or II, London, ca.1705.
fields.physical_description: A silver-gilt seal cup and cover; on circular spreading base, rising to a baluster stem and tapering cylindrical threaded cup, the removable domed cover with vase shaped finial, the base engraved with a coat of arms and crest within a baroque cartouche, engraved with the Royal crown and applied with portrait medallions of William III and Queen Anne, the cover engraved with a crest.

fields.public_access_description:
Cups, salvers and other commemorative objects made from a monarch's Great Seal are among the most lavish British silver with examples surviving from the late seventeenth century, when the British monarchy was restored, onwards. Keepers of the Seal were responsible for the monarch's personal - 'privy' - seal, one of the most influential roles in the kingdom in early modern times. One of the oldest offices with roots in the fourteenth century, the office still exists with the Lord Privy Seal as one of the five Great Officers of State.

The law required that the Great Seal had to be defaced upon the monarch's death. Frequently the seals remained in the possession of their respective holder and were often transformed into silver plate commemorating the office. Large cups were a typical object to be made from seals in the early eighteenth century. Sir Nathan's successor, Lord Cowper had two cups made from his seal only a few years later. The Wright Seal Cup is possibly the earliest example of such a cup and shows the portraits of the two monarchs he served in this office, William III and Anne.

This cup is part of the Rosalinde and Arthur Gilbert Collection on loan to the Victoria and Albert Museum, London. Sir Arthur Gilbert and his wife Rosalinde formed one of the world's great decorative art collections, including silver, mosaics, enamelled portrait miniatures and gold boxes. Arthur Gilbert donated his extraordinary collection to Britain in 1996.

fields.history_note: Sir Nathan Wright was Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal from 1700-1705. Provenance: Sir Nathan Wright (1654-1721). Bequethed to his son, George Wright of Gayhurst, Buckinghamshire. By descent to Mrs R. L. Cameron, sale, Christie's, London, lot 176, 26/03/1975. (through S. J. Phillips) Christie's, New York, lot 400, 17/10/1996. The arms are those of Wright impaling Ashby for Sir Nathan Wright (1654-1721). He married Elizabeth, second daughter of George Ashby of Quenby, Leicestershire, in 1676. Sir Nathan Wright was recorder of Leicester from 1680 to 1684 and in 1688, Serjeant at Law in 1692 and knighted and made King's Serjeant in 1697. He received the Great Seal from William III at Hampton Court on 2 May 1700 when he was made Privy Councillor. After the death of William III Wright surrendered the Great Seal to Queen Anne who returned it to him with the title of Lord Keeper. She is recorded to have remarked "That she would not have done so, if there had been a worthier man in the kingdom to whom she could have delivered it" (Campbell, Lives of the Chancellors, p. 208). In 1705 Wright was succeeded by Lord Cowper as Keeper to whom he would have surrendered Queen Anne's seal. The present cup therefore is likely to have been made from King William's seal. The portrait of Queen Anne was added to commemorate Wrights holding of the seals of both monarch.
